overview_of_class: 2017 is the 100th anniversary of the Russian Revolution. To make sense of the significance of this anniversary, this unique course provides an introduction to modern Russia's rich cultural history, from the revolutionary fervor of the 1920s to Stalinist repression, from the vitality of official and unofficial art during the post-Stalin "thaw" to the new artistic revolutions that followed the collapse of the Soviet Union. We will grapple with fundamental questions such as how historical and political contexts shape the arts, how the arts have been and can be used to imagine new worlds, how foreign ideologies interact with national cultures, and how scholars' distinct disciplinary tools and frameworks shape their approaches to the study of Russia's history, politics, and artistic culture.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: 2017 is the 100th anniversary of the Russian Revolution. To make sense of the significance of this anniversary, this unique course provides an introduction to modern Russia's rich cultural history, from the revolutionary fervor of the 1920s to Stalinist repression, from the vitality of official and unofficial art during the post-Stalin "thaw" to the new artistic revolutions that followed the collapse of the Soviet Union. We will grapple with fundamental questions such as how historical and political contexts shape the arts, how the arts have been and can be used to imagine new worlds, how foreign ideologies interact with national cultures, and how scholars' distinct disciplinary tools and frameworks shape their approaches to the study of Russia's history, politics, and artistic culture.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: 1) Achieve an understanding of the chronology of and principal developments in Soviet and post-Soviet Russian history. 2) Achieve an understanding of how historical context and politics shape artistic and cultural production, and vice versa. 3) Achieve an understanding of how "Russian" culture interacts with international influences. 4) Achieve an understanding of how scholars' disciplinary tools shape their insights. 5) Build a vocabulary to articulate the development of Soviet culture, focusing on artistic movements (e.g., Futurism, Constructivism, Socialist Realism) and aesthetic techniques (e.g., estrangement, biomechanics, montage). 6) To develop skills of close reading, critical visual analysis, active listening, engaged discussion, and making clear, well-reasoned arguments in writing and speaking.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Exam, final: (30%)
Exam, mid-term: (20%)
Papers: 4-5 page paper (25%)
Discussion section: Participation in discussion section and class attendance (15%)
Writing assignments: 2-page précis, written about a local event or exhibition related to the 2017 anniversary (10%)

Clark, "God Is Not Cast Down" (short excerpt), from Farewell to an Idea Christina Kiaer, Imagine No Possessions, excerpts Robert Leach, "Revolutionary theatre, 1917-1930" Aleksandra Kollontai, "Vasilisa Malygina" Lydia Chukovsky, "Sofia Petrovna" Anna Akhmatova, "Requiem" Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich Solzhenitsyn, "Matrena's Home" Sozhenitsyn, "Incident at Krechetovka Station" Alexei Yurchak, Everything was Forever until it was No More (2007)?one chapter Daniel Treisman, The Return: Russia's Journey from Gorbachev to Medvedev (Free Press, 2011) - Chp 5: "The Unraveling" (pp. 163-196) Alexander Dallin, "Causes of the Collapse of the USSR," Post-Soviet Affairs 8, 4 (1992) John Bushnell, "The Brief Post-Soviet Life of the Soviet Graffiti Argot," in Russia's Century of Revolutions: Parties, People, Places (2012), pp. 173-94, Sheila Fitzgerald, The Russian Revolution (3rd edition), ISBN 978-01-99237678.

overview_of_class: This course examines major developments, movements, controversies, and figures in American religious history from the end of the Civil War, as the nation struggled to make sense of the carnage of war and to apportion responsibility, to the 1930s, when economic crisis strained social bonds and intimate relations and challenged Americans to rethink the nature of public responsibility. Topics include urban religion; religion and changing technologies; African American religion; religion and politics; and the religious practices of immigrants and migrants.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lectures and discussions; close reading of documents; classroom conversation.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be evaluated on the basis of a final examination; two short papers (2-3 pp.) based on the readings; and three very brief quizzes during the quarter at specified times.
